Authors:
Adama Faye, Jean-Christophe Pintaud, William John Baker,
Bonaventure Sonké, Thomas LP Couvreur
Title:
A plastid phylogeny of the African rattans
((Ancistrophyllinae, Arecaceae)
Keywords:
Palmae, tropical rain forest, climbing habitat, liana,
atpI-atpH, psbA-trnH
Abstract:
Over one third of African palms are rattans, e.g. climbing
palms. The subtribe Ancistrophyllinae (subfamily Calamoideae) contains
most of these with 21 species represented by three genera: Eremospatha,
Laccosperma and Oncocalamus. African rattans are mainly restricted to
the tropical rain forests of Central and West Africa and play an
important role in the local economy thanks to their use in furniture
making. Here, we present a species level phylogeny of the
Ancistrophyllinae based on four plastid intergenic spacers (psbA-trnH,
psbZ-trnfM, atpI-atpH and rps3-rpl16) sequenced for 80% of the species
found in the subtribe (17/21). Data were analyzed using maximum
parsimony, maximum likelihood and Bayesian inference methods. Our
results show that subtribe Ancistrophyllinae is strongly supported as
monophyletic, as are the three genera. However, relationships between
the genera remain unresolved. Our analyses provide details on the
relationships between species within Eremospatha and Laccosperma, but
not in Oncocalamus. The species E. cabrae and E. dransfieldii were
recovered with strong support as sister, together forming a highly
divergent clade sister to the rest of the genus. The four plastid
markers used here provide useful levels of resolutions and could be
considered in other species level analyses in palms.
